title: Why does the network drop the same nodes thousands of times?
body:
Hi there,

Recently I re-synced (fast-sync) 5 servers (bare-metal) from scratch, each server has plenty of CPU/Memory/Bandwidth and all of them have exactly the same hardware.

However, only 4 of the servers synced without issues, the final one seemed to take 10x as long (and still ongoing).

Looking at the logs the problem the lagging server seems to have is that it has countless messages indicating "Stalling state sync, dropping peer".

However strangely enough it seems that the server spends thousands of times dropping the same few peers.

-Should it not blacklist these peers after a while?
-It is connected to at least 4 other fully synced nodes via direct 1Gbps links, why do these nodes not help sync the server?


Output counting which peers were dropped:



It could be related to the fact that it is connected to a lot of lightsync nodes even though this node is not done syncing yet:
````
    205 les/1
     74 les/1,les/2
     21 eth/62,eth/63,par/1,par/2,pip/1
     16 eth/62,eth/63
      7 eth/63
      2 eth/63,les/1,les/2
````

 

#### System information
Linux Centos 7.3 running: docker run -ti -p 30303:30303 docker.io/ethereum/client-go --maxpeers 1010 --lightserv 90 --lightpeers 1000

Geth/v1.8.0-unstable-9d187f02/linux-amd64/go1.9.2
Very good question, been wondering the same myself

Also seeing the same thing, this node has been syncing for days now, and most of its update messages are with `count=0` and stuff like:

```
WARN [12-27|16:06:31] Stalling state sync, dropping peer       peer=03f178d5d4511937
```

Which is one of the peers OP complained about too.

Edit: here's a longer example of what we're talking about

Maybe 95% of my log messages are about dropping peers. Another 4.9% are `count=0` state entry imports, and very very rarely, I'll see a nonzero state entry import. Not a block header or receipt in sight, even though I'm not fully synched.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
